sentence: Sheldon Allan Silverstein  (September 25, 1930 – May 10, 1999) was an American writer, poet, cartoonist, songwriter, and playwright.
His songs have been recorded and popularized by a wide range of acts including Johnny Cash, The Irish Rovers, and Dr. Hook & the Medicine Show.
Sheldon Allan Silverstein was born into a Jewish family in Chicago on September 25, 1930.

In 1957, Silverstein became one of the leading cartoonists in Playboy, which sent him around the world to create an illustrated travel journal with reports from far-flung locales.
During the 1950s and 1960s, he produced 23 installments called "Shel Silverstein Visits..." as a feature for Playboy.

These illustrated travel essays were collected by the publisher Fireside in Playboy's Silverstein Around the World, published in 2007 with a foreword by Hugh Hefner and an introduction by music journalist Mitch Myers.

Sheldon Allan Silverstein  (September 25, 1930 – May 10, 1999) was an American writer, poet, cartoonist, songwriter, and playwright.
Sheldon Allan Silverstein was born into a Jewish family in Chicago on September 25, 1930.
He grew up in the Logan Square neighborhood of Chicago, where he attended Roosevelt High School.
He grew up in the Logan Square neighborhood of Chicago, where he attended Roosevelt High School.
He then attended the University of Illinois, from which he was expelled.
He enrolled in the Chicago Academy of Fine Arts, which he was attending when he was drafted into the U.S. Army; he served in Japan and Korea.

His first book Take Ten, a compilation of his military Take Ten cartoon series, was published by Pacific Stars and Stripes in 1955.
After returning to Chicago, Silverstein began submitting cartoons to magazines while also selling hot dogs at Chicago ballparks.

On June 25, 2019, two decades after Silverstein's death, The New York Times Magazine listed him among hundreds of artists whose material had been destroyed in the 2008 Universal Studios fire.
He was buried at Westlawn Cemetery in Norridge, Illinois.
